summary: This document is an email chain from March 2021 discussing efforts by law enforcement to obtain travel records for Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell from 1994 onward. It reveals that a CBP TFO could not access the records informally, necessitating a formal FDR or MLAT request. The email includes detailed passport information for both individuals.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Her travel records and multiple passports (US, UK, France) from 1994-2001 are being sought by law enforcement.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: His travel records and multiple US passports are being sought by law enforcement, with a note referencing the FBI New York Field Office's Child Exploitation Human Trafficking task force.

connections.description: Both are subjects of a joint law enforcement inquiry for travel records, indicating their activities are being investigated together.

events.title: Initial request for Epstein/Maxwell travel records
events.description: A law enforcement official sends a request to a CBP TFO seeking travel records for Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell beginning in 1994.

events.title: Update on travel records request
events.description: An email update states the CBP TFO was unable to access the travel records informally, recommending proceeding with a formal FDR or MLAT request.

keyFacts: Law enforcement was actively seeking travel records for Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell from 1994 onward as of March 2021.
The request had to proceed via formal legal channels (FDR or MLAT) after an informal attempt by a CBP TFO failed.
Ghislaine Maxwell held multiple passports from the US, UK, and France between 1994 and 2001.
Jeffrey Epstein held multiple US passports, with one expiring in 2005.
The inquiry was connected to the FBI New York Field Office's Child Exploitation Human Trafficking task force (EFTA00154297).
